For me, the biggest thing that always works in a positive way is education.
I ask people why they feel the way they do and about any fears they have… especially with vaccines it’s typically just lack of understanding and information overload without knowing what to trust.

I do find a video (like ASAP Science!) and watch it WITH THEM and help to answer questions they have and help them to understand and make an informed decision.

Often times people will be drop dead stubborn over a fear of making an uninformed decision and you can help by getting them informed! Think of it like giving them a knowledge injection!

Now if they’re deep into some kind of community and obsessed with appearances and refuse to do something that goes against the group… there is literally nothing you can do, just don’t even waste your time. I’m not even joking..
the SECOND they bring up Facebook or whatever, just walk away. It’s not worth it. People would literally rather DIE than feel like they look bad to their group.. no amount of education and logic will help someone getting medical information from a MAGA group on Facebook and who gets all of their news in the form of minion memes. Just back away slowly. They have one foot on a landmine and you are NOT a bomb disposal expert. Just tip toe away quietly and save yourself! Seriously. Studies show that you literally cannot change beliefs that are constantly being reinforced. It’s like killing a boss in a video game with instantly regenerating health.. you might make some headway but the second you stop talking with them, they check Facebook and reinforce their stance and ignore everything you just said. The only option is to remove them from the echo chamber of misinformation but like I said… you’re not a Bomb disposal expert.. you could theoretically defuse that landmine under their foot, but you lack the expertise and steady hand. In those cases you genuinely do need some expert help. Deeply reinforced beliefs that go against common sense and logic go FAR beyond vaccines or elections, there is a root problem that pushes people to seek validation and support instead of seeking knowledge and truth. You cannot address those problems. So don’t try.
You can and probably will push them deeper into the nonsense. It’s like quicksand, if you try to pull someone out by wiggling them they will just sink deeper, you can’t force it.. you NEED expertise and help. You will never survive by just tackling them off the landmine.. sure, they’ll be off the mine… but the damage will be severe and probably irreparable.

I hope this helps someone.
I’ve had this problem before, because I have cancer and my family tried to get someone to get vaccinated so I don’t die.. my nephew also has an immune disease too.. it’s serious. But we just pushed and wiggled and made things worse.
Since then I did a TON of research to see what we did wrong and the answer was, everything. The unintuitive answer is literally to just leave them alone. If you can seek professional help, absolutely do that! But if you can’t… just don’t push. Don’t try to prove anything and do not ever try to win against them.

Good luck! Stay safe out there!

So my mother is vaccine hesitant for two reasons: one because one of her nieces once had a really bad reaction to a vaccine (full body, painful and itching rash combined with fever) and the doctor just said, that it couldn't be from the vaccine and that my mums brother is anti-vax if he thinks a vaccine can cause this. The fifth doctor just said, that this is most likely an allergic reaction to an ingredient of the vaccine, she should take this medicine and next time get the other vaccine, which doesn't have this ingredient. Rash was gone in 2 days and she has never had another reaction afterwards, as they just skipped the vaccines with the problematic ingredients.
Secondly when I was a baby and was scheduled to get my first vaccine, I had a flu with pretty high fever etc. So my mum went to the doctor with me and told them at the entrance that she isn't here because of the vaccination appointment, but because I am sick. In the treatment room the doctor came in syringe already filled, grabbed my arm and wanted to give me the triple vaccine without even asking if there is anything else. My mum had to pull me away forcefully, declaring that she isn't here to get me vaccinated, but that I am pretty ill and that the vaccine appointment needs to be rescheduled until I am better. Doctor started getting angry, because she had wasted a dose of the vaccine and told my mum, that she was probably one of those insane anti-vaxers and she hopes I die from the measles, because then it's only my mums fault. My mum just grabbed me and rushed out. Two weeks later I got the vaccine at another doctor.
Due to these incidents my mum is usually critical when it comes to vaccines and trys to compare the risks (because there are always some risks) with the overall benefits instead of just blindly getting it.
However she was also the first one to get the CoV19-Vaccine in our family, because she considered it important and necessary. People, who are vaccine critical/hesitant are not anti-vax, they usually just want more information to be able to estimate their personal risks and the overall benefits of the vaccines appropriately. And they also want pharma concerns to take responsibility for vaccine injuries or deaths as well as doctors taking averse reactions to vaccines more seriously, because this still barely happens, but would restore a lot of trust.

While I disagree with the end result, being "vaccine hesitant" myself (important to note that this only applies to COVID and flu, I'm all for and up to date on my other vaccines), I completely 100% agree with you're approach.

We're all human beings with different thoughts, beliefs, desires, and fears and I love that your approach takes those things into account.

As an RN, I don't use my title to push or condemn either decision (nor do I convey that being an RN gives me the ability to speak as an absolute authority on the matter).

That being said, I do have education / training regarding disease transmission and prevention. It is not at the immunology PhD level, of course, but they are the basics upon which everything else is built. I simply use this knowledge to explain my own personal un-answered questions, concerns, fears, and beliefs regarding the vaccine.

The entire field of nursing / medicine operates within the infinite shades of gray, few things are black and white, all good or all bad. More often than not, the answer to a simple question is an opaque answer, "it depends."
Even a life saving procedure can have debilitating or deadly side effects. We constantly weight the pros against potential side effects and damage when we review each possible intervention.

I say all of that to mean, I fully acknowledge that I may be wrong in my personal choice, but after weighing the pros and cons of the information that I have available to me, I have chosen that the benefits do not significantly outweigh the risks (or meet the level of medical necessity) for me and those that I interact with (As of late, I am no longer practicing nursing, unrelated to COVID or vaccines).

I love the idea of actual communicating with people. But I personally think no one should be 'encouraging' or 'persuading' anyone to have any medical interventions of any kind. I believe in non-biased, evidence based information which can be delivered clearly to each person and then they can make the informed choice that is right for them. Because it is their body and it doesn't matter who else it affected. Any medicines which is put into someone should be done by their own informed consent. Yes, we are a society. But you can't force societies problems as a hole on people as individuals. Because we all have individual rights, especially to our own bodies. It's actually one of the only things in this world we now have control over.

The thing is, it's not actually about you. This decision affects them the most. Not just physically, it can also affect someone emotionally. I am not surprised some people do not trust their own governments and health care services, as I think we forget there have been victims in the past when they put their trust in medical professionals believing something to be safe when unfortunately, it turns out it was not(if we think about the Thalidomide tragedy and the mass transmission of HIV to patients receiving infected blood). So I completely understand if someone chooses not to trust their healthcare providers, especially when we are talking about minorities or vulnerable people, who have been let down countless of times.

Vaccines should 100% be your own choice, all we can do is make sure people can access the right information and evidence to empower them to make the right decision for them.

I am a healthcare professional who has been fully vaccinated, but I respect and advocate for patient choice.

What i love about this is the fact hat you’re bringing to light a massive problem most people have when it comes to beliefs others hold that they don’t. Nothing is solved with violence, threats, insults, or aggression. Removing the “I’m right and you’re wrong” and “us vs them” mentality in an argument is the best way to not only understand the other person, but to make them feel understood and will help them be more open minded to what you are hoping to persuade them on. However, going into a conversation hoping to persuade someone rarely works long term. You’ll either convince them and they do something they’ll resent you for later because they weren’t permanently convinced, or they just won’t be convinced at all. Approach disagreements with understanding, patience, compassion, and facts. More times than not: everyone will be better for it.

The thing is vaccines don't stop you from getting a disease, especially one that has a lot of variants. We were able to more or less stop polio and small pox, but they do not mutate much, and some places with low vaccine rates do have polio present. It is why we need a yearly flu vaccine, and will probably need a yearly covid vaccine. It is also partially why we need boosters for things like measles, mumps, hep a, whooping cough, etc. They do not mutate as much as the flu or covid, but your immune system also begins to forget diseases after several years of not seeing them, so you need to remind it of the disease. Even then if you come in close contact you can still get said diseases, but they tend to be less dangerous to you and last a shorter period of time in your body, since your body is able to respond to it quicker. So in theory the covid vaccine is likely to decrease the chances of you getting seriously sick or being sick for a long time, but it does not stop it from infecting you entirely. This makes people hesitant, plus the fact that it is a new technology.. mRNA trigger instead of a denatured virus...and the fact they said if enough people got the vaccine we could get back to normal...which enough people did but they keep moving the goal posts..makes people even more skeptical. Add the fact that the governments have also hurt people before with false claims, such as the Tuskegee incident when they purposefully infected certain minorities with syphilis and lied about curing it, makes even more people worried about it. The inability to sue if you have a bad reaction also does not help. Makes people skeptical, to say the least.

Actually I quite like this approach as someone who is a current 5 on this scale. I’m not extremely for or against the vaccine. I admit when it first came out it was scary to think about it. I was scared to be one of the first to get it, and was determined to wait a while before I got it myself. The main reason I have yet to get it is my extreme fear of needles. And I mean EXTREME. Like, it isn’t just something I hate, it’s something I have to be tied down to get and I’m pretty sure they can’t physically restrain me now that I’m an adult… For some more clarity on how extreme my fear is: When I was in a car accident and in the hospital hooked up to a heart rate monitor… The doctors came in and told me I needed to get an IV. I immediately went into freak out mode and started bawling my eyes out and screaming to my mom. My heart rate increased so much that the heart rate monitor went into alarm mode. If my mom hadn’t have been there with me I think it would have been a lot worse. But now I have no family near me and no one I trust enough like that to go with me to get the vaccine… I’m not quite sure what to do or even which one to get if I do eventually get it. Lots of people just tell me to put my big girl pants on and just do it but that isn’t really helpful. In fact, that makes me want to go get it less because it’s just so patronizing and it really downplays my extreme fear. The fact that I’m so scared of needles I would rather risk my health than get a needle should be a clear indicator of just how scared I am of injections. Plus, I have a tumor on my arm from an injection I got a few years ago that went wrong. I’m mentally scarred by these things, and I don’t know how to get over it. But having people yell at me for not being vaccinated because of it really doesn’t help 🥺 If anyone has advice or information on anything, I’d appreciate it! I’ve been struggling with this for a very long time, but I’m definitely not an anti-vaxxer! But I do hate it when people tell me my extreme fear of needles isn’t an excuse because that just invalidates me and my fears. Making me feel bad about myself isn’t going to make me want to get the vaccine any more than it did before they said those things to me…

My response to this post is not for or against the subject of this video. The reason for my post is, when I smell sales tactics/strategies, I’m interested and ganna share my 2 cents.

0-10 is one of many closing questions. The question isn’t if one is “hesitant,” the question is WHY they’re “hesitant.”
Assuming you’re in some form of sales, you’re trying to gain some leverage based off their response, and flesh out any objections to help move the conversation forward.
WHY they’re hesitant isn’t an objection, it’s a decision. And like some, if not most, people do research before they make a decision. Therefore they’ve already made up their mind (whether or not to buy what you’re selling).

There are many brands to choose from in regards to the subject of this video. Much like there are many brands of cars to choose from. It’s not if one is better than the other, because they’re all going to do the same thing at the end of the day, it’s if it is a trustworthy and reputable brand. For example, one might prefer Tim Hortons coffee over Star Bucks because it’s cheap, and the other because it caters to their lifestyle, prefer the quality more etc…

They (the buyer) have already considered the cost for their beverage, this is a simplistic example.

Regarding the subject of this video, the brands all have varying degrees of influence, reputability and truth-worthiness. But thats where choice stops (with the brands) and pros vs cons begins.

If one is 3/10, asking what would make them a 10 isn’t so easy, unless you hold hostage their job, and their capacity to buy food etc… With that said, it’s no longer a closing question, it’s a hostage negotiation.

There are a million reasons why one would and why one wouldn’t.

In my opinion 0-10 scale is more of a soft close/trial close question. If you really want to move a conversation forward, respectfully, and no one’s jobs are at stake, ask:

“I see you’ve done a lot of research, and that is good, not a lot of people do that. Out of curiosity, if all of these brands were all the same, did exactly the same thing, and had a 100% efficacy rating, which one would you choose? [Wait for response]
Oh and by the way, how great would it be to _________”

At this point they’re either going to unload more objections or role play with you (activating their right brain). Once they’re in a creative state, it’s easier to move the conversation forward, so long you add positives (how great would it be to have made a big decision, how would you feel once you’ve gotten it out of the way…)

If they’ve already made up their mind, don’t fight. It’s an uphill battle and respect their decision.

Oh man I wish! So, important thing some might not realize, there are deep-seated ethnic and racial reasons for vaccine hesitancy among specifically Indigenous and African Americans.

Not all of them! But if you're struggling to understand why someone with one or both of those backgrounds is refusing and perhaps can't fully articulate why, it's because of history. Like, all of the history between those two groups and colonial society.

I'm Indigenous, and I developed my own word for this issue, I call it the Blanket Mentality. See, one of the earliest instances of white society "helping" us was to give us blankets intentionally infected with Smallpox, Influenza and other viruses for which my ancestors had no immunity.

Then both the native and black communities were experimented upon without their knowledge, sterilized without consent, and basically f*cked with by "scientists".

Whether or not you decide to call me an anti vaxxer for what I'm about to say is completely up to you, but I would very much appreciate it if things are kept civil. It's not that I don't trust vaccines in general, I'm just very skeptical about the covid vaccine. When you think back to the development for other vaccines, scientists spent many years working on them to make sure they were safe and effective. The covid vaccine was developed over the span of less than a year, and didn't have nearly enough time to run it through testing. On top of that, the long term side effects are still largely unknown. Just because you're perfectly healthy weeks or months after you take it doesn't mean you won't necessarily be facing probems (whether they be mild or severe) years down the road. If I were to ever bring up skepticism about the covid vaccine to someone who's pro vax, they might say something like "it was developed by scientists who spent years getting their degrees and studying this sort of thing, so it can be trusted and you have no right to question it", or "you have to get vaccinated because you're selfish if you dont". I don't see those as ringing endorsements to want to get vaccinated. I see it as though I'm almost being manipulated or threatened to do it. And when people say these doctors can be trusted because of all their scientific accomplishments, the way I see it is that the degrees and awards make them qualified on the subject, but not necessarily trustworthy. How do we know that these doctors are being honest when they claim the vaccine is super safe and effective. Well, that was my 2 cents, and if you're one of those people who is completely in favor of the covid vaccine, than more power to you. But as of right now, I think I'm gonna wait just a little bit longer and see where things end up before I even consider taking it.

The moment I understood medical statistics, specifically relative risk reduction, absolute risk reduction and numbers needed to treat for the vaccines were using, I went from “I’ll wait and see” to “I’d rather not”. The high relative risk reduction (“efficacy”) is meaningless without also assessing absolute risk reduction. relative being the ratio of the rates of incident between without and with treatment, and absolute being the magnitude of the actual difference between with and without.
Absolute risk reduction for me was too small to get excited about a high efficacy.

Without absolute risk reduction, you can’t tell the difference between a drop from a 10% to a 1% chance, and a 0.1% chance to 0.01%, as both examples here are 90% effective.
It’s contingent on Base Risk and how it changes to New Risk, the issue is that not everyone’s Base Risk is the same.

Just look at the estimations for infection fatality ratios by age, an earlier paper from dec 2020 calculated 10 year olds at 0.002% IFR and 80+ at 15% IFR.

Now reduce both those by 90%.

Certain people only marginally benefit, and some people benefit a lot, but this is lost in conversation because absolute risk reduction was never discussed from the beginning.


When I understood antigenic drift for a mutating RNA virus and how were using a vaccine with the tip of a single antigen (the S1, tip of the spike), I understood that the vaccine has little to no redundancies or breadth of immune response. Necessitating that any S1 mutations would serious cut into efficacy, as it’s efficacy effectively exists only on a razor’s edge. I understood an escape variant would emerge.
When I understood that S1 vaccines elicit a strong humoral immune response but a weak intercellular response I went from “I’d rather not” to “I don’t see a reason to get it”. Especially know that disabled virus vaccines and recovery grant a strong intercellular response. But novavax and covaxin aren’t available, and the live attenuated COVI-VAC is a ways away still.

When the conversation is consumed by “waning antibodies”, I can only ask, “do people not realize that plasma cells die, and only a fraction remained long lived plasma cells? The role of memory B is to make more plasma cells when re-exposed, the logic for boosters makes no sense.”

When I learned that chronic high antibody titres is an organ stress, and is prolonged can lead to hyper viscosity syndrome, my concerns grew.
When I learned that we don’t know WHY myocarditis or any of the mRNA side effects occur, I became more concerned.

One can speculate, like how the LNP causes cells to express the S1 on the cell membrane may cause CD8+ T cells or NK cells to see those cells as infected, thus they will kills those cells, seems plausible.
Or how the spike in the blood is known to cause Renin-angiotensin system problems from the days of SARS-CoV-1, and since the vaccine spike is stuck in prefusion confirmation, it may bind to ACE2 like an antagonist, such that if Ang 2 can’t be down regulated from ACE2, it may take the AT1R pathway which can lead to vasoconstriction, inflammation and fibrosis.

These are unacceptable concerns for a vaccine.

When I learned I had covid, I knew my risks before hand, and it played out as expected. So, I’m never getting the vaccine, at best it’s marginal benefit along a greater risk profile. Risk-benefit analysis is not in the benefit’s favour.


Ultimately, when you want more people to get vaccinated, demand a better vaccine.
